author: Bego√±a Del Teso
title: Cr√≠tica de 'La semilla de la higuera sagrada' (2024): El velo, el m√≥vil, la pistola
text:
Secciones
Servicios
Destacamos
Hay una escena hermos√≠sima, cargada de sutileza y decencia humana en esta excelente pel√≠cula dirigida por un cineasta que, habiendo sido sentenciado a ocho a√±os de prisi√≥n y a ser azotado, hubo de escapar del obsceno r√©gimen de Teher√°n a pie por las monta√±as.
Director Mohammad Rasoulof.
Int√©rpretes Soheila Golestani, Setareh Maleki, Missagh Zareh, Mahsa Rostami.
Fotograf√≠a Pouyan Aghababayi.
Duraci√≥n 168 minutos.
Tan ... hermosa, tan sutil, tan delicada, tan intensa que Justin Chang reconoce en su cr√≠tica para el 'New Yorker' haber sentido humedec√©rsele los ojos de emoci√≥n, ternura y tristeza. En esa escena Najmeh, la esposa de Iman, el juez de instrucci√≥n que en los primeros momentos de un filme que dura 168 imprescindibles minutos parece hasta √≠ntegro, cura la mejilla de una muchacha amiga de sus hijas, que acaba de ser tiroteada en la cara durante las protestas (¬°Mujer, vida libertad!) por la muerte de aquella joven asesinada por la polic√≠a de la moral por llevar mal puesto el velo.
Najmeh es todav√≠a una mujer fiel y leal. A su marido. Al gobierno teocr√°tico. A su Dios. A las costumbres y a la ley. Para ella algo habr√° hecho Sadaf para que le rompan la cara con perdigones. Y sin embargo, por esa lealtad que se debe a s√≠ misma se los va extrayendo con sumo cuidado en una secuencia que, seguro, tambi√©n conmovi√≥ al jurado de Cannes pues premi√≥ el filme. Y al p√∫blico del Zinemaldia que lo consider√≥ su favorito, apoyando as√≠ su distribuci√≥n en salas.
Cine total, cine en estado puro. Cine pol√≠tico. Cine social. Cine humano. Cine hecho, tambi√©n, a golpe de m√≥vil valeroso. Cine de terror. De un terror que crece paranoico mucho antes de que llegue el final terrible, filmado con, de nuevo esas palabras, pura excelencia cinematogr√°fica. Hay un thriller de alto voltaje en esta pel√≠cula soberbia. S√≠, un 'thriller' porque poco a poco en casa de Najmeh, Rezvan y Sana se instala el horror dom√©stico mientras afuera unos matan y otros mueren. Cine puro.
.

author: Ariana St Pierre, WGME
title: chevron-right
text: WESTBROOK (WGME) ‚Äì Authorities say a Maine man, who was under the influence, crashed into a police cruiser while driving the wrong way in Westbrook. Police say they received a report of an erratic driver on Stroudwater Street heading towards William Clarke Drive around 8:25 p.m. on Sunday. Police say officers spotted the vehicle driving the wrong way on William Clarke Drive, heading directly towards them. They activated their emergency lights, but the driver did not stop and crashed into them, according to police. Police say the push bumper on the cruiser absorbed the hit, and the officers were not injured. The officers arrested the driver, identified as 45-year-old Matthew McGovern of Westbrook. McGovern was charged with OUI, aggravated driving to endanger, reckless conduct, unlawful possession of scheduled drugs, and criminal mischief. He was taken to the Cumberland County Jail. Police say Westbrook officers made four OUI arrests over the weekend, including this crash. ‚ÄúAs the weather gets nicer, we remind everyone to make smart choices and not getting behind the wheel if they are impaired by alcohol or drugs,‚Äù the Westbrook Police Department said.

author: Maureen Groppe
title: Supreme Court takeaways from arguments in historic Trump immunity case
text: Maureen Groppe Bart Jansen WASHINGTON ‚àí The [Supreme Court](/story/news/politics/2023/02/10/how-many-justices-supreme-court-list-justices-2023/10796688002/) appeared inclined Thursday to reject former President Donald Trump‚Äôs historic claim that he‚Äôs [immune from prosecution](/story/news/politics/elections/2024/04/15/trump-immunity-supreme-court-founding-fathers/73331041007/) ‚Äì but the justices could still limit the charges he faces and delay his trial on election interference charges. The court [could decide](/story/news/politics/elections/2024/04/23/supreme-court-trump-immunity-election-interference/73263297007/) that the lower courts need to investigate whether immunity applies to Trump‚Äôs actions requires more investigation by the lower courts before Trump can be tried. That would likely make it impossible for a [trial to be finished](/story/news/politics/2023/12/26/donald-trump-criminal-trials-timeline/71969783007/) before voters decide in November whether to return Trump to the White House. "Trump had much more success than many court watchers expected,‚Äù said John Yoo, a former Justice Department official under George W. Bush. ‚ÄúOnly the three liberal justices seemed to reject the idea of immunity outright.‚Äù If Trump [becomes president](/story/news/politics/elections/2024/04/21/poll-trump-biden-election-immigration-economy/73404469007/), he could order the Justice Department to dismiss the charges against him. Here are the takeaways from the court's more than two-and-a-half hours of debate. Trump's lawyer agrees some alleged acts can be prosecuted It was a conservative justice ‚Äì and one of Trump‚Äôs three nominees on the court ‚Äì who looked for ways for Trump‚Äôs trial to proceed. Justice Amy Coney Barrett first got Trump‚Äôs attorney to agree that there‚Äôs no immunity for a president‚Äôs private actions, as opposed to those taken in his official capacity as president. Reading from the indictment, Barrett then asked John Sauer if some of the charges against Trump involved only private conduct. What about conspiring with a private attorney to file false allegations or to using another attorney to spread claims about election fraud he knew were false,‚Äù she asked. Sauer disputed the characterization of the allegations but said that, if true, they cover private actions. When it was the Justice Department‚Äôs turn at the bench, Barrett asked Michael Dreeben about the possibility of the special counsel trying Trump just on the charges that undisputable include only private actions. ‚ÄúThe special counsel has expressed some concern for speed and wanting to move forward,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIs another option for the special counsel to just proceed based on the private conduct and drop the official conduct?‚Äù Dreeben said the two are interrelated because the steps Trump took as president made his other actions more likely to succeed. ‚ÄúWe would like to present that as an integrated picture to the jury so that it sees the sequence and the gravity of the conduct and why each step occurred,‚Äù he said. Debate over how quickly trial could proceed Since even Trump‚Äôs attorney agreed that the former president is not immune from prosecution from some of the charges, the big question is whether the Supreme Court will direct the lower court to take additional action before seating a jury. That will determine whether a trial can begin before the November election. Chief Justice John Roberts asked Sauer what should happen if the Supreme Court latches on to his concession that private acts can be prosecuted. Sauer said the district court should have to determine which charges meet that definition before Trump can be tried. Justice Sonya Sotomayor backed the Justice Department‚Äôs position that the district court judge can decide those issues as the trial unfolds. "So I'm not sure that I understand why your problems couldn't be taken care of at trial with an instruction if we believe ‚àí if the court were to find ‚àí I'm not even sure how they could ‚àí but if it were to find that some publicacts could not be the basis of criminal liability," she told Sauer. Rick Hasen, an election law expert at the UCLA School of Law, predicts the court‚Äôs decision will be closer the government's position than it will be to Trump‚Äôs sweeping immunity argument. But the justices are likely to find different ways of getting there, which means the opinion will take longer to write, and a majority will want further proceedings. ‚ÄúThe bottom line is that Trump is likely to get what he wants ‚Äì a further delay of this election subversion case, maybe pushing it to after the election,‚Äù Hasen wrote . Justices revive debate about presidents killing political opponents with immunity When Sauer argued for Trump at the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals, Judge Florence Pan pressed him on whether a president could order Seal Team 6 to kill his opponent and be immune from prosecution unless impeached and convicted. Sauer said the hypothetical president could only be prosecuted after he was impeached and convicted in Congress. [Justice Samuel Alito said](/story/news/politics/2024/04/25/trump-supreme-court-immunity-ham-sandwich-eclipse/73453731007/) he didn‚Äôt want to slander Seal Team 6 because its members are honorable and are bound under the Uniform Code of Military Justice not to obey unlawful orders. ‚ÄúI'm sure you've thought of lots of hypotheticals where a president could say, ‚ÄòI'm using an official power,‚Äô and yet the president uses it in an absolutely outrageous manner,‚Äù Alito said. Sauer tried to steer the conversation away from what the immunity would cover. But Justice Elena Kagan asked whether it could be an official act for a president to order a military coup. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an official act, but that sure sounds bad, doesn't it?‚Äù Kagan asked. Sauer said it sounded bad but that the framers of the Constitution put checks in place such as impeachment to prevent something like that from happening. ‚ÄúWell, it certainly sounds very bad, and that's why the Framers have a whole series of structural checks that have successfully for the last 234 years prevented that very kind of extreme hypothetical,‚Äù Sauer said. Justices question whether presidents can pardon themselves No president has yet pardoned himself and neither the courts nor the Justice Department have issued opinions on whether it‚Äôs possible. But the threat of criminal charges looming over former presidents after the leave office is why Trump contends presidents must be immune from prosecution for their official acts. Justice Neil Gorsuch raised the issue of whether presidents can pardon themselves because of fears a successor could charge them criminally. He suggested presidents might pardon themselves every four years to avoid the threat. ‚ÄúIt seems to me like one of the incentives that might be created is for presidents to try to pardon themselves,‚Äù Gorsuch said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve never answered whether a president can do that. Happily, it‚Äôs never been presented to us.‚Äù Sauer, Trump‚Äôs lawyer, said if the court rules presidents have immunity, justices wouldn‚Äôt have to worry about whether presidents could pardon themselves. ‚ÄúThe legality of that has never been addressed,‚Äù Sauer said of self-pardons. Alito said the court needs to know the Justice Department‚Äôs position on whether presidents could pardon themselves because if there is no immunity, ‚Äúwon‚Äôt the predictable result be that presidents in the last couple of days of office will pardon themselves from anything they might have been conceivably charged with committing?" Dreeben, counselor to Justice Department special counsel Jack Smith, said the department hasn‚Äôt taken a position on whether a president could pardon himself, although a member of the Office of Legal Counsel wrote that ‚Äúthere is no self-pardon authority.‚Äù Dreeben said the issue has only arisen in the case of Richard Nixon, who was pardoned by his successor after the Watergate scandal, and in Trump‚Äôs case. But he said a self-pardon would violate a ‚Äúbedrock principle‚Äù that people shouldn‚Äôt judge themselves. More: [Trump at Supreme Court: Ham sandwiches and solar eclipses: Justice Alito has questions](/story/news/politics/2024/04/25/trump-supreme-court-immunity-ham-sandwich-eclipse/73453731007/) Supreme Court `writing a rule for the ages' in Trump case The justices sounded quite aware of deciding the historic case. Trump is the first former president ever to face criminal charges. Potential immunity from charges isn‚Äôt written into the Constitution. And the high court has never ruled on what immunity the president might enjoy. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre writing a rule for the ages,‚Äù Gorsuch said. Justice Brett Kavanaugh said he was thinking about how the court‚Äôs ruling would affect future presidents because a previous Supreme Court decision was mistaken in upholding independent counsels that could investigate presidents, a law that has since lapsed. "I'm not focused on the here and now of this case," Kavanaugh said. "I'm very concerned about the future." Alito characterized the case as ‚Äúmore than just a quarrel.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat we do is going to apply to all future presidents,‚Äù Alito said.

author: Chris Phelan
title: Ice T, Wife Coco & Daughter Chanel Are So Merry in Their Matching Christmas Sweaters
text:
Create a free profile to get unlimited access to exclusive show news, updates, and more!
Ice T, Wife Coco & Daughter Chanel Are So Merry in Their Matching Christmas Sweaters
The SVU star and his family were clearly in the holiday spirit this Christmas ‚Äî while wearing Body Count merch.
It looks like it was a very merry ‚Äî and fashionable ‚Äî Christmas for [Ice T](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/people/ice-t) and his family!
In a December 25 Instagram post, the longtime [Law & Order: Special Victims Unit](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/show/law-order-special-victims-unit) star shared adorable photos of his family all decked out in festive merch from [his band, Body Count](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/law-order-svu-ice-t-career-recap). (You can snag one of your own Body Count holiday sweaters [at their online store](https://bodycountmerch.net/products/xmas-sweater-pre-sale)).
Ice T, his [wife Coco Austin](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/ice-t-on-jimmy-fallon-wife-coco-daughter-chanel-birthday-interview), and their nine-year-old [daughter Chanel](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/ice-t-daughter-chanel-new-lookalike-pic) were in full Christmas spirit mode as they prepared to open their impressive haul of gifts.
"Happy Holidays from the 'Ice Family' üéÑüéÖü§∂üéÅü•Ç," they captioned the sweet roundup.
The super-sweet Christmas pics mark another successful photo op for the fam, who's been known to take full advantage [of unique places like elevators](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/ice-t-daughter-family-vacation-outifits) to capture heartwarming family moments. The clan has also been known to travel through airports in the [most delightful fashion ](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/ice-t-family-riding-electric-suitcases-airport)[ever](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/ice-t-family-riding-electric-suitcases-airport) ‚Äî guess there's never a dull moment when Coco and Ice T are Mom and Dad!
And the musician and SVU star is quick to credit his wife for creating Christmas magic.
"Christmas ‚Äî Coco does all that," Ice T told [Jimmy Fallon](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/people/jimmy-fallon) on December 14. "If it wasn't for her, there would be no holidays, as far as Ice T is concerned."
[RELATED: Ice T Reveals a Golden Rule That Keeps Him & Wife Coco From Arguing: ‚ÄúWe Just‚Ä¶"](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/ice-t-on-jimmy-fallon-wife-coco-daughter-chanel-birthday-interview)
Ice T, Coco, and Chanel wore matching Body Count Christmas sweaters by the tree
Ice T never misses an opportunity to rep the heavy metal band [he's been fronting](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/ice-ts-voice-is-rock-roll-dynamite-covering-pink-floyd) since 1990. Though most music fans know Ice T was one of the most prominent West Coast rappers of the '90s, he also has roots in metal ‚Äî and the future SVU star first formed the band nearly 35 years ago.
Body Count recently released Merciless, their eighth studio album, on November 22, 2024, with industry outlet [Metal Hammer](https://www.loudersound.com/reviews/body-count-merciless) calling the album an "ice-cold knock-out." Ice T and Body Count performed their Pink Floyd cover, "Comfortably Numb," on [The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/show/the-tonight-show-starring-jimmy-fallon) on December 4.
Of course, headbanging runs in the family ‚Äî even Chanel has been known to [join her dad on stage](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/ice-t-daughter-chanel-performed-with-body-count-band) to unleash the rock from time to time.
[RELATED: Matthew McConaughey Singing "Christmas (Baby Please Come Home)" Is Pure Holiday Joy](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/matthew-mcconaughey-singing-christmas-baby-please-come-home-jimmy-fallon-haim)
Ice T's daughter, Chanel, turned nine in November
Speaking of little Chanel ‚Äî a [social media sensation](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/ice-t-daughter-chanel-tonight-show) in her own right ‚Äî Ice T's family recently came together to celebrate an important milestone: her ninth birthday.
Chanel appeared equally shocked and embarrassed at the birthday surprise that occurred in an Arizona restaurant ‚Äî it was [a cute and ](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/ice-t-wife-coco-austin-daughter-chanel-surprise-birthday)[loud](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/ice-t-wife-coco-austin-daughter-chanel-surprise-birthday)[ moment](https://www.nbc.com/nbc-insider/ice-t-wife-coco-austin-daughter-chanel-surprise-birthday) that we're sure Chanel will remember for the rest of her life.
topics: Arts, Culture and Entertainment->online media outlet

author: Delia Reynolds
title: DataLink Unveils 8 Technology Trends Shaping Healthcare in 2024: AI, ML, and Personalized Medicine at the Forefront
text: Technology Trends Shaping Healthcare in 2024: DataLink Predictive Analytics for Personalized Medicine DataLink, a leading provider of data-driven healthcare solutions, has identified predictive analytics as a key trend shaping healthcare in 2024. This technology enables personalized medicine, early risk detection, and intervention strategies, allowing healthcare professionals to tailor treatments to individual patients‚Äô needs. Precision Healthcare with Computer Vision Another significant trend highlighted by DataLink is precision healthcare with computer vision in AI-powered medical imaging. This advancement allows for more accurate and detailed medical imaging, aiding in the diagnosis and treatment of various conditions. Augmented Reality and Virtual Reality in Healthcare DataLink also emphasizes the use of augmented reality and virtual reality in medical training, mental health well-being, and remote physical therapy. These technologies offer innovative ways to improve training, mental health treatment, and physical therapy, enhancing patient care and outcomes. As we move into 2024, the healthcare industry is on the brink of a transformative journey fueled by AI and ML, As seen in the coverage by Saurabh Bhargava, vice president of data science at DataLink. The year ahead is set to maintain a continuous and ongoing focus on approaching patient care, utilizing vast amounts of data, and addressing industry challenges.

author: Nupur Thapliyal
title: Delhi High Court Rejects Plea To Offer Prayers On Shab-E-Barat At Site Of Demolished 600-Yr-Old Mosque In Mehrauli
text: Delhi High Court Rejects Plea To Offer Prayers On Shab-E-Barat At Site Of Demolished 600-Yr-Old Mosque In Mehrauli Nupur Thapliyal 23 Feb 2024 8:27 AM GMT The Delhi High Court on Friday dismissed a plea seeking permission to offer prayers and visit the graves on the occasion of Shab-e-Barat at the site of recently demolished 600-year-old mosque, Masjid Akhonji, in city's Mehrauli area. The mosque, along with Madrasa Bahrul Uloom and various graves, were demolished by the DDA on January 30. Justice Purushaindra Kumar Kaurav dismissed the application seeking unhindered entry in the graveyard and site of the mosque of the persons wanting to offer night long prayers and visit graves of their elders, beginning Sunday and ending 30 minutes after sunrise on Monday on Shab-e-Barat. The court dismissed the application moved by Managing Committee of Delhi Waqf Board in a petition pending since 2022. ‚ÄúAt this stage, this court, under the facts of the present case, is not inclined to pass any directions. The application is accordingly dismissed,‚Äù the court said. Justice Kaurav observed that as of now, the site in question is in the possession of DDA and the court is already seized of the main petition which will be heard on March 07. ‚ÄúThe prayer in question relates to the nature of a mandatory injunction. The respondents in their status report have unequivocally states that the structure has already been demolished and that the order of status quo passed by this court is being maintained on the site,‚Äù the court said. Advocates Shams Khwaja appearing for the Managing Committee of Delhi Waqf Board contended that the urgency of filing the application is Shab-e-Barat, which is the occasion of forgiveness where Muslims offer prayers throughout the night in the mosque and visit graveyards. He submitted that the mosque was 700 years old which was illegally demolished by DDA officials. However, the counsel appearing for the Delhi Waqf Board opposed the application and said that the mosque was not 700 years old and is not a waqf property. After hearing the parties, the court dismissed the application. Earlier this month, the court had directed DDA to maintain status quo on the site. It however clarified that the status quo order was passed only with respect to the khasra number where the mosque was situated and will not act as a bar on the DDA to carry out its action on adjoining areas. It is the case of the Managing Committee of Delhi Waqf Board that the mosque and madrasa were demolished in a brazen manner. It is claimed that the Imam of the mosque, Zakir Hussain, and his family were left without shelter and their hutment was also demolished. Title: THE MANAGING COMMITTEE OF DELHI WAQF BOARD v. THE GOVERNMENT OF NCT (GNCT), DELHI & ORS.

organizations.name: managing committee of delhi waqf board
